title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: psychinterpreter package automatically interprets psychometric analysis results using Large Language Models (LLMs). LLMs AI systems (like ChatGPT, Claude, open-source alternatives) can understand generate human-like text. Instead manually examining complex statistical output guessing patterns represent, get clear, human-readable interpretations actionable insights. Currently supported analyses: Factor Analysis - Interpret factor loadings suggest meaningful factor names Planned analysis classes: Gaussian Mixture Models - Interpret cluster profiles Item Response Theory (IRT) - Interpret item diagnostics Cognitive Diagnostic Models (CDM) - Interpret Q-matrix patterns Use package : run psychometric analysis (e.g., factor analysis, clustering) Want automated, data-driven interpretations results Need quickly understand complex patterns data

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: starting, make sure : Analysis results - psych::fa(), lavaan::efa(), similar functions Variable descriptions - brief explanations variable measures language model - recommend Ollama (free, runs locally, offers cloud-powered models Ollama account)

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: ’s complete workflow factor analysis using Big Five personality data just lines:
code: library(psychinterpreter) library(psych) library(ollamar)  # 1. Run factor analysis fa_result <- psych::fa(bfi[,1:25], nfactors = 5, rotate = "oblimin")  # 2. Describe your variables var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("A1", "A2", "A3", ...),   description = c("Am indifferent to others", "Inquire about others", ...) )  # 3. Get LLM interpretation interpretation <- interpret(   model_fit = fa_result,   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # 4. View results print(interpretation) plot(interpretation)

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: tutorial demonstrates package using factor analysis, workflow applies analysis types become available. Let’s walk complete example using Big Five Inventory (BFI) personality data. Load packages ’ll need: BFI dataset contains 25 personality items measuring Big Five traits. ’s data looks like: item descriptions: Perform standard exploratory factor analysis 5 factors: View factor loadings: Create data frame mapping variable names descriptions: Now use interpret() get automatic factor interpretations: Note First time using Ollama? Install Ollama ollama.com ollamar package: install.packages("ollamar") Pull model: ollamar::pull("gpt-oss:20b-cloud") Start Ollama server running interpret() Print interpretation report: output shows: - Suggested factor names - variables load factor - brief interpretation factor represents View suggested factor names: Create visual representation factor loadings:  plot shows variables load strongly factor, making easy see factor structure glance. Save interpretation file:
code: # Install pacman if needed for easy package loading if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")  # Load packages pacman::p_load(   "psychinterpreter",  # This package   "psych",             # For factor analysis   "DT",        # For nice tables   "dplyr",             # For data manipulation   "pander"             # package for pretty printing ) # Load Big Five Inventory data data("bfi") data("bfi.dictionary")  # Keep only the 25 personality items (remove demographics) bfi_items <- bfi[, 1:25] bfi_dict <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ] head(bfi_items, 5) |>   as.data.frame() |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) bfi_dict |>   select(Item) |>   as.data.frame() |>   DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) fa_result <- psych::fa(   bfi_items,   nfactors = 5,   rotate = "oblimin",  # Oblique rotation   fm = "ml"            # Maximum likelihood ) # Extract and display loadings loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |>    as.data.frame()  round(loadings_matrix, 2) |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) variable_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi_dict),   description = as.character(bfi_dict$Item),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  head(variable_info, 10) |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) interpretation <- interpret(   model_fit = fa_result,   variable_info = variable_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" ) FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Number of factors: 5 Loading cutoff: 0.3 LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud Tokens:   Input: 1780   Output: 1715 Elapsed time: 9.26  SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  • Factor 1 (9.6%): Emotional Instability • Factor 2 (7.7%): Social Compassion • Factor 3 (7.4%): Reserved Introversion • Factor 4 (7.7%): Task‑Oriented Conscientiousness • Factor 5 (6.3%): Idea‑Driven Openness  Total variance explained: 38.7%  DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Factor 1 (ML2) - Emotional Instability Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 9.65%  Variables:   1. N1, Get angry easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .852)   2. N2, Get irritated easily. (Positive, Very Strong, .817)   3. N3, Have frequent mood swings. (Positive, Strong, .665)   4. N5, Panic easily. (Positive, Moderate, .439)   5. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .413)  LLM Interpretation: ML2 is dominated by the five neuroticism variables (N1 through N5), with loadings ranging from .393 to .852. These items represent irritability, mood swings, moodiness, affective lability, and panic, all core facets of emotional volatility. The factor thus captures a unified construct of affective instability. Its near-zero correlation with ML5 and ML4, and only modest correlations (.23 with ML1, -.21 with ML3) reinforce its distinctiveness. The absence of significant loadings on extraversion or conscientiousness items ensures discriminant validity, while the strong internal consistency implied by the high loadings indicates excellent convergent validity. ML2 explains 9.6% of the variance and represents the latent trait commonly labeled Neuroticism in personality research.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 2 (ML5) - Social Compassion Number of significant loadings: 7 Variance explained: 7.69%  Variables:   1. A3, Know how to comfort others. (Positive, Strong, .668)   2. A2, Inquire about others' well-being. (Positive, Strong, .603)   3. A5, Make people feel at ease. (Positive, Strong, .577)   4. A4, Love children. (Positive, Moderate, .456)   5. E4, Make friends easily. (Positive, Weak, .362)   6. A1, Am indifferent to the feelings of others. (Negative, Weak, -.360)   7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .303)  LLM Interpretation: ML5 is strongly loaded by agreeableness items (A2, A3, A4, A5) and moderately by social‑interaction items (E3, E4). Items such as inquiring about others’ wellbeing, comforting others, and fostering ease in others illustrate the compassionate, pro‑social core of agreeableness. The emotionalthroghness of E3 (captivate people) and E4 (make friends easily) add an interpersonal warmth dimension. The factor’s low correlations with ML2 and ML3 (–.03, .20) and moderate correlation with ML1 (.23) corroborate its construct distinctiveness. High convergent loadings and a coherent theoretical meaning justify naming the factor Social Compassion, explaining 7.7% of data variance.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 3 (ML1) - Reserved Introversion Number of significant loadings: 7 Variance explained: 7.36%  Variables:   1. E2, Find it difficult to approach others. (Positive, Strong, .667)   2. E1, Don't talk a lot. (Positive, Strong, .565)   3. E4, Make friends easily. (Negative, Strong, -.527)   4. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .420)   5. E5, Take charge. (Negative, Weak, -.394)   6. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .357)   7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Negative, Weak, -.341)  LLM Interpretation: ML1 is marked by positive loadings on introvert‑leaning extraversion items (E1 Don’t talk a lot, E2 Find it difficult to approach others) and negative loadings on extroverted cues (E3 captivate people, E4 make friends easily, E5 take charge). This pattern delineates a Reserved Introversion trait—high scores indicate reticence, difficulty in approaching, and a preference for solitude. Moderately high negative load on E3 and E4 ensures the factor diverges from sociability. ML1’s small correlation with ICU (<.30) and weaker loadings on other factors indicate good discriminant validity. The factor accounts for 7.4% of total variance and captures the emotional reserve dimension of personality.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 4 (ML3) - Task‑Oriented Conscientiousness Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 7.71%  Variables:   1. C4, Do things in a half-way manner. (Negative, Strong, -.643)   2. C2, Continue until everything is perfect. (Positive, Strong, .638)   3. C5, Waste my time. (Negative, Strong, -.570)   4. C3, Do things according to a plan. (Positive, Strong, .564)   5. C1, Am exacting in my work. (Positive, Strong, .532)  LLM Interpretation: ML3 is comprised almost entirely of conscientiousness items: planning (C3), exacting work (C1), striving for perfection (C2) load positively, while careless (C4), wasted time (C5), and half‑way attitude load negatively. These opposing loadings delineate a clear, internally coherent construct of task orientation versus diligence. The factor shows only weak cross‑loadings (ML2 = –.21, ML5 = .20) and high convergent validity, representing a distinct conscientiousness dimension. This factor accounts for 7.7% of variance and maps onto the traditional Conscientiousness trait, emphasizing personal responsibility, organization, and goal attainment.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 5 (ML4) - Idea‑Driven Openness Number of significant loadings: 6 Variance explained: 6.25%  Variables:   1. O3, Carry the conversation to a higher level. (Positive, Strong, .633)   2. O1, Am full of ideas. (Positive, Strong, .534)   3. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Negative, Strong, -.522)   4. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Negative, Moderate, -.441)   5. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .379)   6. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .315)  LLM Interpretation: ML4 is driven by Openness items: abundant ideas (O1), higher‑level conversation (O3), reflective thought (O4) load positively, whereas avoidance of difficult reading (O2) and deep probing (O5) load negatively, delineating a creative, intellectual openness orientation. The positive loading on E3 (captivate people) and modest positive on E5 (take charge) complement the openness profile. Its correlations with ML5 (.23) and ML3 (.20) are weak to moderate, reinforcing discriminant validity. ML4 explains 6.3% of variation and captures the imaginative, intellectual engagement aspect of personality, aptly named Idea‑Driven Openness.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ print(interpretation) FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Number of factors: 5 Loading cutoff: 0.3 LLM used: ollama - gpt-oss:20b-cloud Tokens:   Input: 1780   Output: 1715 Elapsed time: 9.26  SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  • Factor 1 (9.6%): Emotional Instability • Factor 2 (7.7%): Social Compassion • Factor 3 (7.4%): Reserved Introversion • Factor 4 (7.7%): Task‑Oriented Conscientiousness • Factor 5 (6.3%): Idea‑Driven Openness  Total variance explained: 38.7%  DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Factor 1 (ML2) - Emotional Instability Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 9.65%  Variables:   1. title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Load packages ’ll need:
code: # Install pacman if needed for easy package loading if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")  # Load packages pacman::p_load(   "psychinterpreter",  # This package   "psych",             # For factor analysis   "DT",        # For nice tables   "dplyr",             # For data manipulation   "pander"             # package for pretty printing )

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: BFI dataset contains 25 personality items measuring Big Five traits. ’s data looks like: item descriptions:
code: # Load Big Five Inventory data data("bfi") data("bfi.dictionary")  # Keep only the 25 personality items (remove demographics) bfi_items <- bfi[, 1:25] bfi_dict <- bfi.dictionary[1:25, ] head(bfi_items, 5) |>   as.data.frame() |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) bfi_dict |>   select(Item) |>   as.data.frame() |>   DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Perform standard exploratory factor analysis 5 factors: View factor loadings:
code: fa_result <- psych::fa(   bfi_items,   nfactors = 5,   rotate = "oblimin",  # Oblique rotation   fm = "ml"            # Maximum likelihood ) # Extract and display loadings loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |>    as.data.frame()  round(loadings_matrix, 2) |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter
text: Create data frame mapping variable names descriptions:
code: variable_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi_dict),   description = as.character(bfi_dict$Item),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  head(variable_info, 10) |>    DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

title: Getting Started with psychinterpreter

The absence of significant loadings on extraversion or conscientiousness items ensures discriminant validity, while the strong internal consistency implied by the high loadings indicates excellent convergent validity. ML2 explains 9.6% of the variance and represents the latent trait commonly labeled Neuroticism in personality research.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 2 (ML5) - Social Compassion Number of significant loadings: 7 Variance explained: 7.69%  Variables:   1. A3, Know how to comfort others. (Positive, Strong, .668)   2. A2, Inquire about others' well-being. (Positive, Strong, .603)   3. A5, Make people feel at ease. (Positive, Strong, .577)   4. A4, Love children. (Positive, Moderate, .456)   5. E4, Make friends easily. (Positive, Weak, .362)   6. A1, Am indifferent to the feelings of others. (Negative, Weak, -.360)   7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .303)  LLM Interpretation: ML5 is strongly loaded by agreeableness items (A2, A3, A4, A5) and moderately by social‑interaction items (E3, E4). Items such as inquiring about others’ wellbeing, comforting others, and fostering ease in others illustrate the compassionate, pro‑social core of agreeableness. The emotionalthroghness of E3 (captivate people) and E4 (make friends easily) add an interpersonal warmth dimension. The factor’s low correlations with ML2 and ML3 (–.03, .20) and moderate correlation with ML1 (.23) corroborate its construct distinctiveness. High convergent loadings and a coherent theoretical meaning justify naming the factor Social Compassion, explaining 7.7% of data variance.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 3 (ML1) - Reserved Introversion Number of significant loadings: 7 Variance explained: 7.36%  Variables:   1. E2, Find it difficult to approach others. (Positive, Strong, .667)   2. E1, Don't talk a lot. (Positive, Strong, .565)   3. E4, Make friends easily. (Negative, Strong, -.527)   4. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .420)   5. E5, Take charge. (Negative, Weak, -.394)   6. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .357)   7. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Negative, Weak, -.341)  LLM Interpretation: ML1 is marked by positive loadings on introvert‑leaning extraversion items (E1 Don’t talk a lot, E2 Find it difficult to approach others) and negative loadings on extroverted cues (E3 captivate people, E4 make friends easily, E5 take charge). This pattern delineates a Reserved Introversion trait—high scores indicate reticence, difficulty in approaching, and a preference for solitude. Moderately high negative load on E3 and E4 ensures the factor diverges from sociability. ML1’s small correlation with ICU (<.30) and weaker loadings on other factors indicate good discriminant validity. The factor accounts for 7.4% of total variance and captures the emotional reserve dimension of personality.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 4 (ML3) - Task‑Oriented Conscientiousness Number of significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 7.71%  Variables:   1. C4, Do things in a half-way manner. (Negative, Strong, -.643)   2. C2, Continue until everything is perfect. (Positive, Strong, .638)   3. C5, Waste my time. (Negative, Strong, -.570)   4. C3, Do things according to a plan. (Positive, Strong, .564)   5. C1, Am exacting in my work. (Positive, Strong, .532)  LLM Interpretation: ML3 is comprised almost entirely of conscientiousness items: planning (C3), exacting work (C1), striving for perfection (C2) load positively, while careless (C4), wasted time (C5), and half‑way attitude load negatively. These opposing loadings delineate a clear, internally coherent construct of task orientation versus diligence. The factor shows only weak cross‑loadings (ML2 = –.21, ML5 = .20) and high convergent validity, representing a distinct conscientiousness dimension. This factor accounts for 7.7% of variance and maps onto the traditional Conscientiousness trait, emphasizing personal responsibility, organization, and goal attainment.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════  Factor 5 (ML4) - Idea‑Driven Openness Number of significant loadings: 6 Variance explained: 6.25%  Variables:   1. O3, Carry the conversation to a higher level. (Positive, Strong, .633)   2. O1, Am full of ideas. (Positive, Strong, .534)   3. O5, Will not probe deeply into a subject. (Negative, Strong, -.522)   4. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Negative, Moderate, -.441)   5. O4, Spend time reflecting on things. (Positive, Weak, .379)   6. E3, Know how to captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .315)  LLM Interpretation: ML4 is driven by Openness items: abundant ideas (O1), higher‑level conversation (O3), reflective thought (O4) load positively, whereas avoidance of difficult reading (O2) and deep probing (O5) load negatively, delineating a creative, intellectual openness orientation. The positive loading on E3 (captivate people) and modest positive on E5 (take charge) complement the openness profile. Its correlations with ML5 (.23) and ML3 (.20) are weak to moderate, reinforcing discriminant validity. ML4 explains 6.3% of variation and captures the imaginative, intellectual engagement aspect of personality, aptly named Idea‑Driven Openness.  ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ interpretation$suggested_names |>   unlist() |>  data.frame(Suggested_Factor_Name = _) |>   DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE), colnames = "Suggested Factor Name")

text: Q: LLM interpretation seems wrong? LLM bases interpretations variable descriptions statistical results. can: Provide better, descriptive variable descriptions Use bigger LLM. Small models may struggle task structured output requirements. Adjust cutoff hide_low_loadings parameters change results included Add context additional_info parameter Q: Can use different LLMs? Yes! package supports providers supported ellmer package, example: Ollama (local, free): llm_provider = "ollama" OpenAI (API key required): llm_provider = "openai" Anthropic Claude (API key required): llm_provider = "anthropic" Q: set API keys OpenAI Anthropic? Also refer documentation ellmer https://ellmer.tidyverse.org/ package.

title: Usage Patterns of the interpret() Function
text: use Ollama, need make sure start server running . Test connection: use model “gpt-oss:20b-cloud”, needs installed. Since cloud-powered model, need account Ollama logged run model.
code: packages <- c(   "psychinterpreter",   "ellmer",   "ollamar",   "psych",   "lavaan",   "mirt",   "dplyr",   "here",   "DT",   "pander" ) # Load required packages using pacman if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman") Loading required package: pacman pacman::p_load(char = packages) #!/bin/bash  # Check if port 11434 (default Ollama port) is in use if netstat -ano | grep 11434 > /dev/null; then     echo "Ollama is already running." else     echo "Starting Ollama..."     ollama serve fi Ollama is already running. system2("ollama serve", wait = FALSE) Warning in system2("ollama serve", wait = FALSE): '"ollama serve"' not found # test the connection to the Ollama server ollamar::test_connection() Ollama local server running <httr2_response> GET http://localhost:11434/ Status: 200 OK Content-Type: text/plain Body: In memory (17 bytes) # pull the model from ollama if it is not already installed if (!"gpt-oss:20b-cloud" %in% ollamar::list_models()$name) {   ollamar::pull("gpt-oss:20b-cloud") }

Total variance explained: 85.7%  DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────  Factor 1 (MR1) - Engine Performance Number of significant loadings: 4 Variance explained: 84.03%  Variables:   1. disp, Displacement (Positive, Very Strong, .955)   2. cyl, Cylinders (Positive, Very Strong, .953)   3. mpg, Miles per gallon (Negative, Very Strong, -.893)   4. hp, Horsepower (Positive, Very Strong, .862)  LLM Interpretation: Performance factor: high absolute loadings on cylinders, displacement, horsepower, and a strong inverse on miles per gallon. It reflects engine power and efficiency trade‑off, characterizing larger, more powerful engines that consume more fuel. title: psychinterpreter: Advanced Features
text: document demonstrates advanced features psychinterpreter package using Big Five personality data psych package. Big Five Inventory (BFI) widely-used personality assessment measures five major dimensions personality: Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, Neuroticism. ’ll cover major features psychinterpreter including: Basic factor analysis interpretation Persistent chat sessions efficient LLM usage Export functionality across multiple formats Report generation console (output_format = “cli”) markdown style (output_format = “markdown”) Wrappers popular R packages psych, lavaan, mirt

title: psychinterpreter: Advanced Features
code: packages <- c(   "psychinterpreter",   "ellmer",   "ollamar",   "psych",   "lavaan",   "mirt",   "dplyr",   "here",   "DT",   "pander" ) # Load required packages using pacman if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman") Loading required package: pacman pacman::p_load(char = packages)  # Load the BFI dataset and dictionary data("bfi") data("bfi.dictionary")

title: psychinterpreter: Advanced Features

title: psychinterpreter: Advanced Features
text: Perform FA 6 factors identified parallel analysis Loadings: Factor Correlation Matrix Set persistent chat session. use Ollama, make sure start server running . Create variable information dataframe BFI dictionary now generate factor interpretations using specified LLM: FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Number factors: 6 Loading cutoff: 0.23 LLM used: ollama - qwen3-vl:235b-instruct-cloud Tokens: Input: 2243 Output: 443 Elapsed time: 6.2 SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── • Factor 1 (9.2%): Emotional Instability • Factor 2 (7.9%): Introverted Reserve • Factor 3 (7.7%): Conscientious Discipline • Factor 4 (6.8%): Compassionate Engagement • Factor 5 (6.3%): Intellectual Curiosity • Factor 6 (3.1%): Casual Sociability Total variance explained: 41% DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Factor 1 (ML2) - Emotional Instability Number significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 9.22% Variables: 1. N2, Get irritated easily. (Positive, Strong, .851) 2. N1, Get angry easily. (Positive, Strong, .851) 3. N3, frequent mood swings. (Positive, Strong, .639) 4. N5, Panic easily. (Positive, Moderate, .402) 5. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Weak, .389) LLM Interpretation: factor captures neurotic tendencies, high loadings anger, irritability, mood swings. reflects emotional dysregulation vulnerability stress. Low loadings domains confirm discriminant validity, isolating core negative affect construct. ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ Factor 2 (ML1) - Introverted Reserve Number significant loadings: 8 Variance explained: 7.9% Variables: 1. E2, Find difficult approach others. (Positive, Strong, .686) 2. E1, Don’t talk lot. (Positive, Strong, .587) 3. E4, Make friends easily. (Negative, Strong, -.550) 4. N4, Often feel blue. (Positive, Moderate, .436) 5. E5, Take charge. (Negative, Moderate, -.405) 6. O4, Spend time reflecting things. (Positive, Weak, .355) 7. E3, Know captivate people. (Negative, Weak, -.349) 8. N5, Panic easily. (Positive, Weak, .256) LLM Interpretation: Characterized social withdrawal low assertiveness, factor includes reticence difficulty approaching others. Moderate negative loadings sociability leadership reinforce introversion. Weak ties factors support distinctiveness social engagement dimension. ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ Factor 3 (ML3) - Conscientious Discipline Number significant loadings: 6 Variance explained: 7.71% Variables: 1. C2, Continue everything perfect. (Positive, Strong, .680) 2. C4, things half-way manner. (Negative, Strong, -.634) 3. C3, things according plan. (Positive, Strong, .551) 4. C1, exacting work. (Positive, Strong, .547) 5. C5, Waste time. (Negative, Strong, -.541) 6. E5, Take charge. (Positive, Weak, .264) LLM Interpretation: Reflects structured, goal-oriented behavior high loadings perfectionism planning. Negative loadings procrastination half-hearted effort reinforce self-discipline. Low correlations factors confirm unique role behavioral regulation task persistence. ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ Factor 4 (ML5) - Compassionate Engagement Number significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 6.79% Variables: 1. A2, Inquire others’ well-. (Positive, Strong, .688) 2. A3, Know comfort others. (Positive, Strong, .617) 3. A1, indifferent feelings others. (Negative, Strong, -.560) 4. A5, Make people feel ease. (Positive, Moderate, .451) 5. A4, Love children. (Positive, Weak, .391) LLM Interpretation: Captures empathic concern interpersonal warmth, strong loadings inquiring others comforting. Negative loading indifference highlights prosocial orientation. Moderate correlations factors suggest complements, rather overlaps, emotional social traits. ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ Factor 5 (ML4) - Intellectual Curiosity Number significant loadings: 6 Variance explained: 6.27% Variables: 1. O3, Carry conversation higher level. (Positive, Strong, .656) 2. O1, full ideas. (Positive, Strong, .564) 3. O5, probe deeply subject. (Negative, Moderate, -.451) 4. E3, Know captivate people. (Positive, Weak, .392) 5. O4, Spend time reflecting things. (Positive, Weak, .376) 6. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Negative, Weak, -.367) LLM Interpretation: Represents cognitive engagement abstract thinking, high loadings idea generation deep reflection. Negative loadings avoiding complex material reinforce openness experience. Weak correlations factors support distinct role intellectual exploration conceptual depth. ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ Factor 6 (ML6) - Casual Sociability Number significant loadings: 5 Variance explained: 3.12% Variables: 1. O5, probe deeply subject. (Positive, Moderate, .403) 2. O2, Avoid difficult reading material. (Positive, Weak, .353) 3. C4, things half-way manner. (Positive, Weak, .300) 4. E4, Make friends easily. (Positive, Weak, .287) 5. A1, indifferent feelings others. (Positive, Weak, .281) LLM Interpretation: Reflects spontaneous, low-effort social interaction, moderate loadings making friends casual conversation. Weak ties assertiveness emotional depth suggest surface-level sociability. low variance minimal correlations indicate peripheral, context-dependent social style. ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ Let’s check global token usage tracked chat: can also examine prompt: Plot loading matrix factor names:  can check total global token usage:

KEY DEFINITIONS - **Loading**: Correlation coefficient (-1 to +1) between variable and factor - **Significant loading**: Loading with absolute value >= cutoff threshold - **Convergent validity**: Variables measuring similar constructs should load together; for two factors covering similar constructs, the correlation will be highly positive or negative - **Discriminant validity**: Factors should represent meaningfully distinct constructs; for two factors covering similar constructs, the correlation will be near zero - **Factor correlation**: Correlation between factors indicating relationship strength - **Factor interpretation**: Identifying underlying construct explaining variable relationships - **Variance explained**: Percentage of total data variance captured by each factor - **Emergency rule**: Use highest absolute loadings when none meet cutoff    Main Prompt:   # code: # Parallel analysis to determine optimal number of factors pa_result <- fa.parallel(   bfi,   fa = "fa",   n.iter = 100,   use = "pairwise.complete.obs",   main = "Parallel Analysis: BFI Data" ) Parallel analysis suggests that the number of factors =  6  and the number of components =  NA fa_result <- fa(   bfi,   nfactors = pa_result$nfact,   rotate = "oblimin",   fm = "ml" ) summary(fa_result) Factor analysis with Call: fa(r = bfi, nfactors = pa_result$nfact, rotate = "oblimin", fm = "ml")  Test of the hypothesis that 6 factors are sufficient. The degrees of freedom for the model is 165  and the objective function was  0.36 The number of observations was  2800  with Chi Square =  1013.79  with prob <  4.6e-122  The root mean square of the residuals (RMSA) is  0.02 The df corrected root mean square of the residuals is  0.03  Tucker Lewis Index of factoring reliability =  0.922 RMSEA index =  0.043  and the 90 % confidence intervals are  0.04 0.045 BIC =  -295.88  With factor correlations of       ML2   ML1   ML3   ML5   ML4   ML6 ML2  1.00  0.25 -0.18 -0.10  0.02  0.18 ML1  0.25  1.00 -0.22 -0.31 -0.19 -0.06 ML3 -0.18 -0.22  1.00  0.19  0.19 -0.03 ML5 -0.10 -0.31  0.19  1.00  0.25  0.14 ML4  0.02 -0.19  0.19  0.25  1.00  0.02 ML6  0.18 -0.06 -0.03  0.14  0.02  1.00 # Extract loading matrix for interpretation loadings_matrix <- unclass(fa_result$loadings) |> as.data.frame() round(loadings_matrix, 2) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) # Extract factor correlation matrix factor_cor_mat <- fa_result$Phi |> as.data.frame() round(factor_cor_mat, 2) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) variable_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi.dictionary),   description = as.character(bfi.dictionary$Item),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  head(variable_info) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) word_limit <- 50  result <- interpret(   model_fit = fa_result,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "qwen3-vl:235b-instruct-cloud",   #model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud",   # set temperature and seed for reproducibility   params = params(temperature = 0, seed = 42),   variable_info = variable_info,   cutoff = 0.23,   n_emergency = 2,   additional_info = NULL,   sort_loadings = TRUE,   word_limit =  word_limit,   max_line_length = 80,   silent = FALSE,   echo = "none",   output_format = "markdown",   heading_level = 3 ) ℹ Starting fa interpretation... ℹ Creating temporary chat session... ℹ Building prompt... ℹ Querying LLM... ℹ Parsing LLM response... ℹ Creating diagnostics... ℹ Building report... ✔ Interpretation complete! fa_scores <- fa_result$scores |>    # remove rows with NAs   na.omit()  # add names from interpretation colnames(fa_scores) <- result$suggested_names  head(fa_scores) |> round(2) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) gmm_model <- mclustBIC(fa_scores, G = 1:10)  summary(gmm_model) Best BIC values:              VEE,4         VEE,8       VEE,6 BIC      -35035.92 -35045.158874 -35046.9011 BIC diff      0.00     -9.235479    -10.9777 gmm_best <- Mclust(fa_scores, x = gmm_model)  summary(gmm_best) ---------------------------------------------------- Gaussian finite mixture model fitted by EM algorithm ----------------------------------------------------  Mclust VEE (ellipsoidal, equal shape and orientation) model with 4 components:   log-likelihood    n df       BIC       ICL       -17319.11 2436 51 -35035.92 -36105.13  Clustering table:    1    2    3    4  253  541 1534  108 gmm_means <- gmm_best$parameters$mean head(gmm_means) |> round(2) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) gmm_covariances <- gmm_best$parameters$variance$sigma head(gmm_covariances[,,1]) |> round(2) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) gmm_proportions <- gmm_best$parameters$pro gmm_proportions |> as.data.frame() |> round(3) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) gmm_z <- gmm_best$z head(gmm_z) |> round(3) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) print(chat) function (model, messages, tools = list(), stream = FALSE, format = list(),     keep_alive = "5m", output = c("resp", "jsonlist", "raw",         "df", "text", "req", "tools", "structured"), endpoint = "/api/chat",     host = NULL, ...) {     output <- output[1]     if (!output %in% c("df", "resp", "jsonlist", "raw", "text",         "req", "tools", "structured")) {         stop("Invalid output format specified. Supported formats: 'df', 'resp', 'jsonlist', 'raw', 'text', 'tools', 'structured'")     }     req <- create_request(endpoint, host)     req <- httr2::req_method(req, "POST")     if (!validate_messages(messages)) {         stop("Invalid messages.")     }     messages <- encode_images_in_messages(messages)     body_json <- list(model = model, messages = messages, tools = tools,         stream = stream, keep_alive = keep_alive)     if (length(format) != 0 & inherits(format, "list")) {         body_json$format <- format     }     opts <- list(...)     if (length(opts) > 0) {         if (validate_options(...)) {             body_json$options <- opts         }         else {             stop("Invalid model options passed to ... argument. Please check the model options and try again.")         }     }     req <- httr2::req_body_json(req, body_json, stream = stream)     if (output == "req") {         return(req)     }     if (!stream) {         tryCatch({             resp <- httr2::req_perform(req)             return(resp_process(resp = resp, output = output))         }, error = function(e) {             stop(e)         })     }     env <- new.env()     env$buffer <- ""     env$content <- ""     env$accumulated_data <- raw()     wrapped_handler <- function(x) stream_handler(x, env, endpoint)     resp <- httr2::req_perform_stream(req, wrapped_handler, buffer_kb = 1)     cat("\n\n")     resp$body <- env$accumulated_data     return(resp_process(resp = resp, output = output)) } <bytecode: 0x0000016ad4eaa858> <environment: namespace:ollamar>

title: Gaussian Mixture
text: Extract factor scores Find Best Gaussian Mixture Model Fit Best Model Get mean vector, covariance matrix, mixing proportions model fit. Means: Covariance Matrix: Mixing proportions z matrix membership grades every person can check total global token usage:
code: fa_scores <- fa_result$scores |>    # remove rows with NAs   na.omit()  # add names from interpretation colnames(fa_scores) <- result$suggested_names  head(fa_scores) |> round(2) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) gmm_model <- mclustBIC(fa_scores, G = 1:10)  summary(gmm_model) Best BIC values:              VEE,4         VEE,8       VEE,6 BIC      -35035.92 -35045.158874 -35046.9011 BIC diff      0.00     -9.235479    -10.9777 gmm_best <- Mclust(fa_scores, x = gmm_model)  summary(gmm_best) ---------------------------------------------------- Gaussian finite mixture model fitted by EM algorithm ----------------------------------------------------  Mclust VEE (ellipsoidal, equal shape and orientation) model with 4 components:   log-likelihood    n df       BIC       ICL       -17319.11 2436 51 -35035.92 -36105.13  Clustering table:    1    2    3    4  253  541 1534  108 gmm_means <- gmm_best$parameters$mean head(gmm_means) |> round(2) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) gmm_covariances <- gmm_best$parameters$variance$sigma head(gmm_covariances[,,1]) |> round(2) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) gmm_proportions <- gmm_best$parameters$pro gmm_proportions |> as.data.frame() |> round(3) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) gmm_z <- gmm_best$z head(gmm_z) |> round(3) |> DT::datatable(options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) print(chat) function (model, messages, tools = list(), stream = FALSE, format = list(),     keep_alive = "5m", output = c("resp", "jsonlist", "raw",         "df", "text", "req", "tools", "structured"), endpoint = "/api/chat",     host = NULL, ...) {     output <- output[1]     if (!output %in% c("df", "resp", "jsonlist", "raw", "text",         "req", "tools", "structured")) {         stop("Invalid output format specified. Supported formats: 'df', 'resp', 'jsonlist', 'raw', 'text', 'tools', 'structured'")     }     req <- create_request(endpoint, host)     req <- httr2::req_method(req, "POST")     if (!validate_messages(messages)) {         stop("Invalid messages.")     }     messages <- encode_images_in_messages(messages)     body_json <- list(model = model, messages = messages, tools = tools,         stream = stream, keep_alive = keep_alive)     if (length(format) != 0 & inherits(format, "list")) {         body_json$format <- format     }     opts <- list(...)     if (length(opts) > 0) {         if (validate_options(...)) {             body_json$options <- opts         }         else {             stop("Invalid model options passed to ... argument. Please check the model options and try again.")         }     }     req <- httr2::req_body_json(req, body_json, stream = stream)     if (output == "req") {         return(req)     }     if (!stream) {         tryCatch({             resp <- httr2::req_perform(req)             return(resp_process(resp = resp, output = output))         }, error = function(e) {             stop(e)         })     }     env <- new.env()     env$buffer <- ""     env$content <- ""     env$accumulated_data <- raw()     wrapped_handler <- function(x) stream_handler(x, env, endpoint)     resp <- httr2::req_perform_stream(req, wrapped_handler, buffer_kb = 1)     cat("\n\n")     resp$body <- env$accumulated_data     return(resp_process(resp = resp, output = output)) } <bytecode: 0x0000016ad4eaa858> <environment: namespace:ollamar>

text: Purpose: Quick reference Claude Code helping users psychinterpreter R package. technical/architectural details: See dev/DEVELOPER_GUIDE.md Status: Phase 2 Refactoring Complete (2025-11-10) - See dev/DEVELOPER_GUIDE.md section 4.2 details IMPORTANT API CHANGES: - Phase 1 (2025-11-09): - model_fit renamed fit_results - llm_provider llm_model renamed provider model - New config objects: llm_args(), fa_args(), output_args() - Phase 2 (2025-11-10): - interpret_fa() removed entirely (functionality now S3 generic build_model_data()) - New architecture: interpret() → interpret_core() → build_model_data.fa() - 169 tests passing new S3 generic system

title: CLAUDE.md
text: : Automates interpretation exploratory factor analysis (EFA) results using Large Language Models via ellmer package. Main Entry Points: - interpret() - Universal generic (public API interpretations) - chat_session() - Create persistent LLM session (saves ~40-60% tokens multiple analyses) Standards Examples/Tests: - Always use provider = "ollama" model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" - LLM tests: word_limit = 20 (minimum allowed) token efficiency Documentation Structure: - CLAUDE.md (file): Usage guide quick reference Claude Code sessions - dev/DEVELOPER_GUIDE.md: Technical architecture implementation details maintainers - dev/TESTING_GUIDELINES.md: Testing standards patterns - dev/templates/: Ready--copy code templates implementing new model types (GM, IRT, CDM) - dev/MODEL_IMPLEMENTATION_GUIDE.md: Conceptual guide new model type implementation

title: CLAUDE.md
code: library(psychinterpreter)  # 1. Run factor analysis fa_result <- psych::fa(data, nfactors = 3)  # 2. Prepare variable descriptions var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("var1", "var2", ...),   description = c("Description of variable 1", "Description of variable 2", ...) )  # 3. Get interpretation interpretation <- interpret(   fit_results = fa_result,   variable_info = var_info,   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # 4. View and export results print(interpretation)                                    # Print report plot(interpretation)                                     # Visualize loadings export_interpretation(interpretation, "results.md", "md") # Export

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Create session once (saves ~40-60% tokens) chat <- chat_session(   model_type = "fa",   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Reuse for multiple interpretations result1 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa1, variable_info = vars1) result2 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa2, variable_info = vars2) result3 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa3, variable_info = vars3)  # Check cumulative token usage print(chat)

text: interpret() function accepts different input types. arguments named prevent confusion.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Supported model types: - psych::fa(), psych::principal() - lavaan::cfa(), lavaan::sem(), lavaan::efa() - mirt::mirt()
code: # Automatically extracts loadings from model objects interpret(   model_fit = psych::fa(...),        # Or lavaan::efa(), mirt::mirt(), etc.   variable_info = var_info,   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # For custom data structures # Both loadings and Phi can be matrices or data.frames interpret(   model_fit = list(     loadings = loadings_matrix,     Phi = correlation_matrix          # Optional (for oblique rotations)   ),   variable_info = var_info,   model_type = "fa",                  # REQUIRED for lists   llm_provider = "ollama",   llm_model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )

title: CLAUDE.md
text: use : - Single analysis: Pattern 1 (fitted model) - simplest - Multiple analyses: Pattern 3 (chat session) - efficient - Custom data: Pattern 2 (structured list)
code: # Create session once chat <- chat_session(model_type = "fa", provider = "ollama", model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud")  # Use with any model_fit type interpret(chat_session = chat, model_fit = fa_result, variable_info = var_info) interpret(chat_session = chat, model_fit = loadings_list, variable_info = var_info)  # Structured list works too

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # View full prompts and responses interpret(..., echo = "all")  # Check JSON parsing with raw response (same function) interpret(..., echo = "all")

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Control verbosity interpret(..., silent = 0)  # Show report + messages (default) interpret(..., silent = 1)  # Messages only, no report interpret(..., silent = 2)  # Completely silent  # Output formats interpret(..., output_format = "text")      # Default: plain text interpret(..., output_format = "markdown")  # Markdown format

code: # Create color-blind friendly heatmap interpretation <- interpret(...) plot(interpretation)  # Uses blue-orange diverging scale  # Customize cutoff for highlighting plot(interpretation, cutoff = 0.4)  # Save to file library(ggplot2) p <- plot(interpretation) ggsave("loadings_heatmap.png", p, width = 10, height = 8, dpi = 300)  # Further customize with ggplot2 p + labs(title = "My Custom Title") +     theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 16))  # Use package theme for other plots library(ggplot2) ggplot(data, aes(x, y)) +   geom_point() +   theme_psychinterpreter()  # Apply package theme  # Access color palettes directly colors <- psychinterpreter_colors("diverging")    # Blue-white-orange cat_cols <- psychinterpreter_colors("categorical") # Okabe-Ito palette

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Causes & Solutions: 1. many LLM tests → Use cached interpretations instead 2. High word_limit → Set word_limit = 20 tests 3. Large fixtures → Use minimal_* fixtures LLM tests 4. Running CI → Add skip_on_ci() LLM tests

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Cause: LLM returned malformed JSON Package handles automatically via multi-tier fallback: 1. Cleaned JSON parsing 2. Pattern-based extraction 3. Default values debug: Use echo = "" see raw LLM response
code: interpret(..., echo = "all")

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Cause: LLM response exceeded word_limit parameter informational (error). Options: 1. Increase word_limit needed 2. Ignore output quality acceptable 3. Review interpretation verbosity

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Cause: Provider-specific behavior - Ollama: token tracking support (returns 0) - Anthropic: Caches system prompts (may undercount) - OpenAI: Generally accurate Solution: Current version uses max(0, delta) protection prevent negatives

title: LLM-powered interpretation for psychometric analyses
text: 🤖 LLM-Powered Interpretation: Generate human-readable factor names interpretations using state---art language models via ‘ellmer’ package psych::fa() psych::principal() results lavaan::cfa(), lavaan::sem(), lavaan::efa() results mirt::mirt() multidimensional IRT results Auto-extracts loadings factor correlations 📊 Comprehensive Reports: Automatically generate detailed reports text markdown format 📈 Visualizations: Create publication-ready heatmaps factor loadings suggested factor names 💾 Multi-Format Export: Export results TXT MD formats 🎯 Provider Agnostic: Works OpenAI, Anthropic, Google Gemini, Azure, Ollama, via ‘ellmer’ 🔄 Persistent Chat Sessions: Reuse LLM sessions across multiple analyses save tokens reduce costs

title: LLM-powered interpretation for psychometric analyses
code: library(psychinterpreter) library(psych)  # Run factor analysis fa_result <- fa(bfi[,1:25], nfactors = 5, rotate = "oblimin")  # Create variable information var_info <- data.frame(   variable = rownames(bfi.dictionary[1:25,]),   description = bfi.dictionary$Item[1:25] )  # Interpret directly from model object results <- interpret(fa_result,                      variable_info = var_info,                      provider = "ollama",                      model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud")

title: LLM-powered interpretation for psychometric analyses
text: control custom loadings matrices:
code: # Extract loadings manually loadings <- fa_result$loadings  # Use structured list with model_type results <- interpret(   fit_results = list(loadings = loadings),   variable_info = var_info,   model_type = "fa",   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )

title: LLM-powered interpretation for psychometric analyses
text: Use persistent chat sessions save tokens analyzing multiple datasets:
code: # Create reusable chat session chat <- chat_session(model_type = "fa", provider = "ollama", model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud")  # Run multiple interpretations (saves ~40-60% tokens) result1 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa_result1, variable_info = var_info1, silent = 2) result2 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa_result2, variable_info = var_info2) result3 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa_result3, variable_info = var_info3)  # Check cumulative token usage print(chat)

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
text: model_type Character. Type analysis: "fa" (factor analysis), "gm" (gaussian mixture), "irt" (item response theory), "cdm" (cognitive diagnosis model) provider Character. LLM provider (e.g., "anthropic", "openai", "ollama") model Character. Model name (e.g., "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001") system_prompt Character NULL. Optional custom system prompt text override model-specific default system prompt. Use provide institution- project-specific framing LLM (e.g., preferred terminology, audience level, reporting conventions). NULL, model-specific default system prompt used (default = NULL). params List. ellmer parameters (temperature, etc.). Default uses ellmer::params() echo Character. Echo level ("none", "output", ""). Default "none" word_limit Integer. Word limit interpretations (used system_prompt NULL). Default 100.

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
text: chat_session object containing persistent chat session

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
text: chat_session object stores: persistent ellmer chat session model-specific system prompt already loaded Model type, provider, model information Token usage tracking (cumulative input/output tokens across interpretations) Session metadata (number interpretations run, creation timestamp) allows efficient reuse across multiple interpretations without resending system prompt time. Token Tracking Note: package tracks per-interpretation token counts using roles returned ellmer::chat$get_tokens() (user/assistant). providers ellmer wrapper consistently expose system/system_prompt token counts (appears upstream limitation/bug). avoid incorrect cumulative accounting (double-counting negative accumulation), chat_session intentionally include system_prompt tokens package-level cumulative counters (total_input_tokens / total_output_tokens). require provider-specific view includes system prompt tokens, call chat$chat$get_tokens(include_system_prompt = TRUE) directly — note results may vary across providers.

title: Create Analysis Chat Session — chat_session
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create a persistent chat session for factor analysis chat <- chat_session("fa", "anthropic", "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001")  # Use with multiple analyses result1 <- interpret_fa(loadings1, var_info1, chat_session = chat) result2 <- interpret_fa(loadings2, var_info2, chat_session = chat)  # Check token usage print(chat)  # Create session for different model type chat_gm <- chat_session("gm", "anthropic", "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001") } # }

title: Export Factor Analysis Interpretation Report — export_interpretation
text: Invisible TRUE success

title: Export Factor Analysis Interpretation Report — export_interpretation
text: Supported Export Formats: "txt": Exports report plain text format. report interpretation_results generated output_format = "cli", ANSI color codes stripped clean text output. Otherwise, markdown formatting may present. "md": Exports report markdown format. report interpretation_results generated output_format = "markdown", exported proper markdown formatting. Otherwise, export cli version. File Extension Handling: function intelligently handles file extensions: provide file = "my_report", becomes "my_report.txt" "my_report.md" provide file = "my_report.txt", stays "my_report.txt" format="txt" Directory paths preserved: "output/report" → "output/report.txt"

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: Unified interface interpreting psychometric analysis results LLMs. Supports fitted model objects, structured lists, persistent chat sessions efficient multi-analysis workflows.

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
code: interpret(   fit_results = NULL,   variable_info = NULL,   chat_session = NULL,   model_type = NULL,   provider = NULL,   model = NULL,   llm_args = NULL,   fa_args = NULL,   output_args = NULL,   ... )

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: fit_results One : Fitted model object: psych package: fa(), principal() lavaan package: cfa(), sem(), efa() mirt package: mirt() Structured list model components: FA: list(loadings = matrix, factor_cor_mat = matrix) list(loadings = matrix) (loadings factor_cor_mat can matrices data.frames) GM: yet implemented IRT: yet implemented CDM: yet implemented variable_info Dataframe 'variable' 'description' columns describing variables. chat_session Optional. chat_session object created chat_session token-efficient multi-analysis workflows (default = NULL). model_type Character. Type analysis ("fa", "gm", "irt", "cdm"). Required using structured list without chat_session. Automatically inferred chat_session provided (default = NULL). provider Character. LLM provider (e.g., "openai", "anthropic", "ollama", "gemini"). Required chat_session NULL. Top-level convenience parameter (default = NULL). model Character. Specific model use (e.g., "gpt-4o-mini", "claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022", "gemma2:9b"). NULL, uses provider default. Top-level convenience parameter (default = NULL). llm_args List llm_args object. LLM configuration settings. Can created llm_args passed plain list. Contains: system_prompt, params, word_limit, interpretation_guidelines, additional_info, echo. provider/model provided top-level, override values llm_args (default = NULL). fa_args List fa_args object. Factor analysis configuration settings. Can created fa_args passed plain list. Contains: cutoff, n_emergency, hide_low_loadings, sort_loadings, factor_cor_mat (default = NULL). output_args List output_args object. Output configuration settings. Can created output_args passed plain list. Contains: format, heading_level, suppress_heading, max_line_length, silent (default = NULL). ... Additional arguments passed model-specific methods.

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: Model-specific interpretation object: FA: fa_interpretation (see interpret) Future: gm_interpretation, irt_interpretation, etc.

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: arguments named prevent positional confusion. function detects pattern using based arguments provided.

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: Pattern 1: Fitted Model Object Automatically extracts model components fitted objects. Pattern 2: Structured List custom data structures manual extraction. FA, provide loadings (required) optionally factor_cor_mat: Pattern 3: Chat Session (Token-Efficient) Reuse chat session across analyses save tokens.
code: interpret(   fit_results = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" ) interpret(   fit_results = list(     loadings = loadings_matrix,     factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat   ),   variable_info = var_info,   model_type = "fa" ) chat <- chat_session(model_type = "fa", provider = "ollama", model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud") result1 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = model1, variable_info = var_info1) result2 <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = model2, variable_info = var_info2)

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: fa (Factor Analysis): psych::fa(), psych::principal(), lavaan::cfa/efa(), mirt::mirt() gm (Gaussian Mixture): yet implemented irt (Item Response Theory): yet implemented cdm (Cognitive Diagnosis Models): yet implemented

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
text: provider model exposed top-level parameters convenience, dual interface pattern allows argument passed either directly respective configuration object (llm_args, fa_args, output_args). keeps primary signature clean maintaining flexibility

title: Interpret Psychometric Analysis Results — interpret
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(psych) fa_model <- fa(mtcars[,1:4], nfactors = 2, rotate = "oblimin")  var_info <- data.frame(   variable = c("mpg", "cyl", "disp", "hp"),   description = c("Miles per gallon", "Cylinders", "Displacement", "Horsepower") )  # Pattern 1: Fitted model result1 <- interpret(   fit_results = fa_model,   variable_info = var_info,   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Pattern 2: Structured list # Extract loadings from fitted model loadings <- as.data.frame(unclass(fa_model$loadings))  # Option A: Loadings only (orthogonal rotation) result2a <- interpret(   fit_results = list(loadings = loadings),   variable_info = var_info,   model_type = "fa",   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Option B: Loadings + factor correlations (oblique rotation) result2b <- interpret(   fit_results = list(     loadings = loadings,     factor_cor_mat = fa_model$Phi   ),   variable_info = var_info,   model_type = "fa",   provider = "ollama",   model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud" )  # Pattern 3: Chat session (token-efficient for multiple analyses) chat <- chat_session(model_type = "fa", provider = "ollama", model = "gpt-oss:20b-cloud") result3a <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa_model, variable_info = var_info) result3b <- interpret(chat_session = chat, fit_results = fa_model2, variable_info = var_info2) print(chat)  # Check token usage } # }

title: Base Interpretation Class Structure — interpretation
text: Defines base interpretation class related S3 methods. Model-specific interpretation classes (fa_interpretation, gm_interpretation, etc.) inherit base class.

title: Base Interpretation Class Structure — interpretation
text: model-specific interpretation classes inherit base class. Common fields across interpretation types: model_type: Character. Type analysis ("fa", "gm", "irt", "cdm") component_summaries: List. Summaries factors/clusters/items/attributes suggested_names: List. LLM-generated names components interpretations: List. LLM-generated interpretations llm_info: List. Provider, model, token information chat: Chat session object diagnostics: List. Model-specific diagnostic information report: Character. Formatted text report elapsed_time: Numeric. Processing time seconds params: List. Analysis parameters

text: model_data List. Model-specific data structure (loadings, parameters, etc.) model_type Character. Type analysis ("fa", "gm", "irt", "cdm") variable_info Data frame. Variable descriptions 'variable' 'description' columns llm_provider Character. LLM provider (e.g., "anthropic", "openai", "ollama"). Required chat_session NULL (default = NULL) llm_model Character NULL. Model name chat_session Chat session object NULL. NULL, creates temporary session system_prompt Character NULL. Optional custom system prompt override package default. NULL, uses model-specific default system prompt. Ignored chat_session provided (default = NULL) word_limit Integer. Word limit interpretations (default = 100) additional_info Character NULL. Additional context LLM output_format Character. Report format: "cli" "markdown" (default = "cli") heading_level Integer. Maximum line length text wrapping (default = 120) silent Integer logical. Controls output verbosity: 0 FALSE: Show report messages (default) 1: Show messages , suppress report 2 TRUE: Completely silent, suppress output backward compatibility, logical values accepted converted integers. echo Character.
